"Taylor and Bette looked bad in those stills because they were ill, not because they were old. "
Even if they hadn't been "ill" they still would have looked bad. Bette didn't really try to hide it; in fact, you could say she flaunted it. Knowing her face was a wreck she'd go on talk shows, hair all styled, face all made up, wearing clothes unsuitable for a woman her age as if to say, this is me, and if you don't like it fuck off. Liz looked bad due to a lifetime of overeating, alcoholism and drug addiction. Her illnesses didn't help, but her illnesses weren't the cause of the decline in her appearance. But she still wanted to be considered beautiful, so she'd go do public appearances heavily made up, hair (I guess it was a wig) raven black, wearing expensive clothes and dripping with jewels. She didn't look beautiful. She looked sad and pathetic, trying to hang on to her long gone youth and beauty.
Clara Bow got very fat in her later years but her skin still looked great. It was one of her best features, her "soft baby skin", as Louise Brooks described it.
I think it was in her early seventies that Marlene Dietrich retreated to her Paris apartment and never went out again. She'd had an accident, had fallen off the stage due to being drunk in an armor-like, skin tight dress, and that was the beginning of the end. She did NOT want to be photographed in her old age, so she holed up in her apartment. A very good documentary about her was "Marlene", directed by  Maximilian Schell. She would not allow him to film her (she was 81 at the time); you just hear her voice.  She hated the movie, until it started getting great reviews and winning awards.
Poor Judy Garland looked ghastly towards the end of her life. Lifelong drug addiction and alcoholism will do that to you.
Greta Garbo never had any plastic surgery. You'd think with that face she would be desperate to preserve it, but she let nature take its course. She had no vanity. People said that even elderly she still had that incredible bone structure. Garbo smoked and had an occasional drink, but was never a drug addict or alcoholic. She didn't age prematurely, like others did.

It would be hard to find a "final photo" of Norma Shearer. I've seen a few photos of her in her later years, but she eventually became so ill and deranged she was confined to a Hollywood old folk's home. One day a woman came in her room wanting a picture and she started to scream. She probably looked ghastly; white-haired, blind, and since she never had a facelift, probably very wrinkled. Mental illness ran in her family; her sister was a schizophrenic. A visitor said that Norma appeared to be "in the grip of a permanent anxiety attack." A minor actress who was in the home said of her: "she was the biggest of them all, and here she is, blind and dying down the hall. Maybe I haven't have it so tough."

Sue Mengers tells the story of representing Constance Bennett on her contract for Madame X.
Bennett was very stubborn, especially considering she'd been out of the limelight for 20 years and unknown to most of young Hollywood; she  and insisted on lots of impossible clauses in her deal. [quote]I always called her Mrs. Hart in private. She inherited massive residuals from her husband Moss, for My Fair Lady, A Star is Born...
Huh?
Moss Hart was a stage director, so he didn't make real Broadway money after Camelot closed (after his death), nor did he direct the films "My Fair Lady", nor "A Star is Born" for which he wrote the screenplay.  None of those projects threw off considerable residuals after Moss Hart's death in 1961. While Kitty was never poor, she wasn't loaded with cash. She herself worked, and inherited  licensing money from Moss Hart's catalogue, but she didn't make much money at all from those titles mentioned. Frankly, she probably earned more from high schools performing "You Can't Take it With You",  and "The Man Who Came to Dinner".
I was at her home catering the last year of her life, and it indeed was a super duper 12-room spread in one of my favorite NY buildings, but it needed a ton of work. The housekeeper said they got some estimates for the crumbling foyer, but they were "too high". Kitty was a delight. She was warm and friendly, and was hosting a fundraiser for Sloan Kettering. She even sang four songs for the guess (Cole Porter, Jerome Kern,  and Gershwin, of course!). She was dating Roy Neuberger, who was 103 at the time! The kitchen was circa 1972, with a $400 GE stove found in a typical rental flat.
Still, she was dressed to the nines, and was warm and elegant while we set up, even telling me that a painting I was looking at was painted by Irving Berlin as a gift to her many years earlier. I think her children got $17 mil for the joint after she passed away a year later.

Kitty Carlisle Hart was still working when she was 96. She did a full out cabaret act pretty much yearly at Feinstein's right up to the end; she'd even change a few songs in the rundown each go round. She'd yank up her skirt--above the knee--and show her legs!
The patter she'd read from a script on a stand but all the songs were memorized. She sounded just fine, singing what would be a demanding program for any singer, about 13-15 songs, nearly all standards. I saw her multiple times and on a good-voice night she sounded amazing. She could still bring it on "I Could Have Danced All Night" and the acting on "September Song". She'd lead a sing-along on Irving Berlin's "Always" and encore with "Here's to Life."
She dated George Gershwin, she knew Jerome Kern, Cole Porter, Johnny Mercer, Irving Berlin, and of course Lerner and Loewe, pretty much all the NYC-based great theatre songwriters from her Broadway shows. And she had her Hollywood career, some operetta, Moss' career, her TV career, and her career as an ambassador for the arts in New York State to reminisce about. A memorable evening with a remarkable woman who led a long and accomplished life.
